Award.AwardTitle: The macrophysiology of food chain dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many of Earth's ecological systems face substantial future warming that could cause loss of species, erode ecological functioning, and jeopardize environmental services that support human livelihoods. Ecological theory predicts that some species may be resilient to warming if individuals in warmer parts of their distribution have already evolved greater tolerance of high temperature and can migrate to cooler parts as they warm. Less clear is whether these immigrants will be able to play the same functional roles as the former residents; if not, ecological functions could still erode. To test this question, this study will study populations of spider predators and insect prey across a temperature gradient similar to the predicted change in global climate. The thermal tolerances of spiders from north to south will be measured, spiders and prey populations will be experimentally transplanted between parts of the regions to mimic the mixing that might occur due to warming and migration, and the differences in functioning between these experimentally mixed communities and existing communities will be tested. The study will thus improve understanding of the potential for evolution to confer the ability to tolerate changes in climate and thereby increase the resiliency of species to environmental change.

This project will enhance participation of women and minorities in STEM research in the context of environmental problems. It will also help to train a globally diverse and competitive STEM workforce through coursework and hands-on research experiences in evidence-based, applied environmental science. The research infrastructure will be leveraged to develop New Haven Public School STEM curricula on environmental services, biodiversity, and effects of climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Even with substantial efforts to reduce atmospheric greenhouse-gas concentrations, many of Earth’s ecological systems still face substantial climate change. Consequently, there is much concern that species’ inability to tolerate or adapt to changing climate may cause ecological functioning to become substantially altered, in turn, possibly jeopardizing many environmental services that support human livelihoods. However, new theory suggests many species may have greater ability to cope with changes than was once thought, providedthattheir physical and physiological capacities to adapt to climate change are not stretched beyond their evolved limitations. This four-year study tested this new theory by measuring how species cope when pushed toward these limitations, and what that means for ecological functioning. The research studied tolerances and interactions among the same species of spider predators, grasshopper prey and vegetation in field locations spread across their south-north geographic ranges between Connecticut in the south and New Hampshire in the north. The temperature and rainfall patterns across this geographic range resemble the amount of change expected between current conditions and future warming. This allowed a realistic test to see if spider predators will lose their ability to control their insect prey, which would in turn be expected to enable the prey to become damaging pests on the vegetation.   

The study compared the tolerances and performance of spider and grasshopper species and vegetation at five locations separated by evenly spaced distances between Connecticut and New Hampshire.  At each location, species were experimentally housed in cages, in different combinations of spiders, grasshoppers and vegetation. The study closely monitored and measured what the presence and absence of predators meant for the grasshoppers’ survival and impact on vegetation. The study also collected and moved spiders and grasshoppers from the four northerly (cooler, wetter) sites into cages at the Connecticut (warmest, driest) site. This was done to measure how the spiders and grasshoppers interacted in the warmer climate and compare this with outcomes at the other sites. Follow-up measurements of spider and grasshopper physiological performance were conducted for all locations to see if individuals also adapted their physiology to the warmer environment. 

Overall, the study revealed that the spider predators did not cope well with the changing climate. They did not alter their physiology. Instead they retreated to and rested in cooler locations within the vegetation, compared to their behavior in the northerly locations. Grasshoppers however adjusted their physiology to cope with warming, enabling them to remain active in locations where they normally occurred in the vegetation.  Together, the spider and grasshopper responses had the effect of dismantling the predator and prey interaction, where predators lost their control over grasshopper prey. But interestingly, the grasshoppers did not increase their damage to the vegetation, compared to the northerly sites. In fact, the study made the new discovery that the physiological adjustments made by the grasshoppers enabled them to eat less food but use that food more efficiently to meet their survival and reproductive needs. Thus, grasshoppers became less, not more, damaging to vegetation even though predators no longer controlled them.

The study species share physiological coping mechanisms, hunting and foraging behavior with many other kinds of species. Thus, the study’s findings could be more broadly applicable to and tested with other species and ecological systems.  At the very least, the study gives deeper and richer understanding about the mechanisms that link the way species cope with environmental changes and resultant ecological functioning. It further points the way for ecologists to think anew about the capacity for ecological systems be resilient in the face of climate change, suggesting that in some cases environmental services might not become jeopardized even when species change their biological natures to adapt to change.  The findings have been published in top scientific research journals. 

More broadly the research contributed toward training a globally competitive STEM workforce.  The research was able to enhanceprofessional training of 5 persons: 2 postdoctoral associates, a Masters student, and 2 undergraduate senior thesis students. The Postdoctoral Associates are now employed in university teaching and research positions. The Masters student and one of the undergraduate students have gone on to pursue doctoral studies in ecology.  The other undergraduate student is pursuing graduate training to do ecologically informed landscape architecture.  The research also provided 2 high school juniors an opportunity to participate as summer interns at the field site, learning about natural history, field ecology and experimentation on a contemporary environmental issue. These same two high school seniors also conducted laboratory research on the Yale University campus as part of their academic year science fair projects. Both have been admitted to undergraduate programs in natural science. Finally, members of the lab engaged with high school science classes to provide hands-on learning of instrumentation and measuring effects of environmental warming on insect physiological performance.
